item.title: Men With History of Cannabis Use Have Less Cognitive Decline From Early Adulthood to Late Midlife - Pharmacy Times
item.description:
Men With History of Cannabis Use Have Less Cognitive Decline From Early Adulthood to Late Midlife

Publication Date: 2024; Source: Brain and Behavior

This study investigates the relationship between cannabis use and cognitive decline among a male population, finding that those with a history of cannabis use exhibit less cognitive decline as they age compared to nonusers.

  • The study utilized data from the Danish Aging and Cognition (DanACo) cohort involving 5162 men.
  • Findings suggest cannabis users experienced less cognitive decline, averaging 1.3 to 1.5 IQ points less than nonusers.
  • Approximately 39.3% of participants reported using cannabis at least once.
  • No significant relationship was found between the age of initiation of cannabis use and cognitive decline.
  • The study's limitations include a low participation rate (14.3%), which may affect the generalizability of the results.
"Cannabis users had a slightly higher average IQ at conscription, while nonusers experienced a mean cognitive decline of about 6.8 IQ points."

The study provides insight into the long-term effects of cannabis use on cognitive decline, highlighting the need for further research, especially among diverse populations.

item.title: What To Do Under Pressure In The Cold - The Times of India
item.description:
What To Do Under Pressure In The Cold

Publication Date: Unknown Source: Unknown

In cold-pressure situations, it is crucial to remain calm and implement practical strategies to manage the environment and personal safety effectively.

  • Recognize signs of freezing temperatures and potential hazards.
  • Prioritize layered clothing to maintain warmth.
  • Stay hydrated and nourished even in low temperatures.
  • Understand basic survival mechanisms in cold conditions.
“Remaining calm is key to making the right decisions under pressure.”

Preparation and knowledge of one’s environment can greatly enhance safety during cold weather challenges.

item.title: ‘Taxi and ambulance drivers less likely to die from Alzheimer's disease’ - The Week
item.description:
Taxi and Ambulance Drivers Have Lower Alzheimer's Disease Death Rates, Study Finds

Published on: [Publication Date] Source: British Medical Journal

A recent study has uncovered a surprising link between certain professions and a reduced risk of Alzheimer's disease. Researchers analysing death data from the US National Vital Statistics System found that taxi and ambulance drivers had the lowest proportion of deaths due to Alzheimer's disease compared to all other occupations.

The study, published in the British Medical Journal, examined death data from nearly nine million adults across 443 different occupations. Among taxi drivers, only 1% (171 out of 16,658) died from Alzheimer's disease, while 0.74% (10 out of 1,348) of ambulance drivers succumbed to the disease. In contrast, approximately 4% of the general population had Alzheimer's disease listed as a cause of death.

  • The frequent spatial and navigational processing in the jobs may provide a protective effect against Alzheimer's disease.
  • This finding is backed by previous studies on enhanced hippocampal function in taxi drivers.
“In an analysis of nearly all death certificates in the United States, taxi drivers and ambulance drivers, whose jobs require frequent spatial and navigational processing, were found to be the occupations with the two lowest risk-adjusted percentages of deaths due to Alzheimer's disease,” the authors wrote.

While the study's findings are intriguing, researchers caution that no cause-and-effect conclusions can be drawn due to the observational nature of the study. Further research is necessary to determine whether the cognitive demands of these professions can prevent or reduce the risk of Alzheimer's disease.

item.title: Treatment Insights and Evolving Care Options in Vitiligo - Dermatology Times
item.description:
Treatment Insights and Evolving Care Options in Vitiligo

Publication Date: December 2024 Source: Dermatology Times

This article discusses the complexities of vitiligo care and the potential of innovative topical therapies as highlighted by experts during a recent conference.

  • Individualized treatment approaches for pediatric vitiligo emphasized.
  • Innovative therapies such as topical ruxolitinib show promising results.
  • Importance of patient and family education on the condition discussed.
  • Advancements in JAK inhibition and their implications noted.
  • Emotional support is crucial for managing vitiligo's impact on self-esteem.
“We want to explain [to parents] that we continue to have evolution in the field of interventions, which will give both a positive perspective towards management and treatment.” - Lawrence Eichenfield, MD

The evolving landscape includes new therapies that offer hope for improved outcomes in patients with vitiligo, particularly children and adolescents.

item.title: REACH demonstrates model for care, support of migrant persons with TB - The Hindu
item.description:
REACH demonstrates model for care, support of migrant persons with TB

Date: December 17, 2024

Source: Not specified

REACH, a not-for-profit organisation, has demonstrated a comprehensive model to provide tailored care for migrant people with tuberculosis (MPwTB) in Tamil Nadu.

The initiative includes screening, care packages, and community outreach aimed at improving diagnosis and treatment adherence among migrants.

  • 11,564 people with TB screened, 36.6% identified as migrants.
  • Launch of the ‘ARISE’ project for community-based TB and health risk sensitisation.
  • Challenges faced by migrants include stigma and delayed diagnosis.
  • Success rate of TB treatment reached 91% through follow-ups.
  • Recommendations for enhancing TB services tailored to migrants, including multilingual support and community health worker training.
“It is important to understand that migrants are not a homogenous group.” - Ramya Ananthakrishnan, REACH’s director

This project highlights the need for focused healthcare solutions for vulnerable migrant populations to improve TB care and outcomes.

item.title: Diarrhea-causing superbug is on the loose; stirs up trouble in Los Angeles - The Times of India
item.description:
Diarrhea-causing superbug is on the loose; stirs up trouble in Los Angeles

Publication Date: October 2023  Source: The Times of India

A dangerous diarrhea-causing superbug is spreading fast and stirring up trouble in Los Angeles. Researchers have identified a new strain of Shigella bacteria resistant to most antibiotics.

  • UCLA scientists tracked an unusual cluster of Shigella cases from 2023 to 2024, revealing the presence of an extensively drug-resistant (XDR) strain.
  • This discovery has been tagged as ‘alarming’ due to the potential for widespread transmission.
  • Symptoms of Shigella infection can lead to severe diarrhea, especially in vulnerable populations like young children and the elderly.
  • The superbug poses a growing public health concern, with CDC reporting a rise in cases involving XDR strains.
“The discovery of a novel XDR S. sonnei actively spreading in Los Angeles is alarming.” - UCLA Researchers

The emergence of XDR Shigella complicates treatment, with a significant public health threat acknowledged by health officials. The continuous spread necessitates immediate attention in monitoring and managing infections.

item.title: Researchers say drinking coffee could help you live two years longer - Women's Health UK
item.description:
Drinking Coffee Could Help You Live Almost Two Years Longer, Says New Study

Publication Date: December 2023

Source: Women's Health Magazine

Could your morning cup of coffee help you live longer? New research suggests yes.

The analysis conducted by researchers at the University of Coimbra examined over 50 studies on coffee consumption and lifespan.

  • Regular coffee drinkers may add an average of 1.8 years of healthy living.
  • Coffee intake reduces major causes of mortality such as cardiovascular diseases and cancer.
  • Social interaction while drinking coffee can also promote longevity.
‘Coffee does contain polyphenols that have been associated with a decreased risk of adverse health conditions,’ says registered dietitian Jessica Cording.

The study indicates that moderate coffee consumption may offer health benefits and promote a longer life.

item.title: Don't replace home-cooked meals with ready-to-eat foods. Here's why - Firstpost
item.description:
Don't replace home-cooked meals with ready-to-eat foods. Here's why

Published on: December 2024 Source: Firstpost

The increasing consumption of convenience foods in India poses serious health concerns, as a recent study shows that these products are generally high in carbohydrates and fats but low in nutritional value.

  • The demand for convenience foods in India has surged, with revenue projected to grow significantly.
  • A study analyzing over 400 popular items found over 70% of their energy comes from carbohydrates.
  • High sodium and trans fat levels were noted, particularly in soup mixes.
  • Discrepancies were found in product claims versus actual ingredients.
  • Low-GI foods are scarce, impacting diabetes management among a large population.
“Preferably avoid processed foods as much as possible,” Dr. RM Anjana advised.

Consumers are urged to read labels carefully and be cautious about convenience foods due to potential health risks.

item.title: What Role Does Regenerative Medicine Play In The Management Of Type 1 And Type 2 Diabetes? - TheHealthSite
item.description:
What Role Does Regenerative Medicine Play In The Management Of Type 1 And Type 2 Diabetes?

Publication Date: December 2024 | Source: The Health Site

Regenerative medicine holds significant promise for the treatment of type 1 and type 2 diabetes through innovative therapies, potentially reshaping diabetes management.

  • Diabetes is classified into type 1 (autoimmune destruction of insulin-producing cells) and type 2 (insulin resistance).
  • Dr. Pradeep Mahajan discusses promising new therapies like stem cell transplantation and gene therapy.
  • Complications from unmanaged diabetes can include heart disease, kidney damage, and more.
  • Regenerative techniques could help replace damaged cells and enhance the body's healing process.
  • Current research focuses on regenerating insulin-producing cells and improving insulin action.
"Maintaining a good glucose level in the blood is critical...regenerative medicine...focuses on restoring lost normal activities." - Dr. Pradeep Mahajan

In conclusion, regenerative medicine is paving the way for future diabetes treatments, with the potential to transform management practices for both type 1 and type 2 diabetes.

item.title: Bavarian Nordic partners to boost mpox vaccine production - The Pharma Letter
item.description:
Bavarian Nordic partners to boost mpox vaccine production

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: The Pharmaletter

Bavarian Nordic consolidates its partnership with India's Serum Institute to enhance the production of the mpox vaccine Jynneos, facilitating local manufacturing and addressing global vaccine accessibility.

  • Bavarian Nordic has signed a licensing and manufacturing agreement with Serum Institute of India.
  • The deal follows a profit-sharing model without upfront payments, allowing SII to produce and distribute the vaccine in India.
  • It boosts global capacity amidst the push for equitable vaccine access.
  • Both parties will conduct a technology transfer for the vaccine's manufacturing process.
  • SII will manage regulatory approvals in India.
“The agreement enables local manufacturing and distribution in India under a profit-sharing model.”

This partnership is pivotal in increasing vaccine availability in light of ongoing health challenges and reflects the commitment to equitable distribution of healthcare solutions.

item.title: How bat poop turned deadly for two men growing marijuana - The Times of India
item.description:
How bat poop turned deadly for two men growing marijuana

Publication Date: Unknown
Source: Unknown

Two marijuana growers faced severe health consequences due to exposure to bat droppings, which can harbor dangerous pathogens.

  • The incident highlights the often-overlooked health risks associated with animal waste.
  • Authorities are warning individuals involved in similar activities to take precautions.
  • This is a rare case, emphasizing the unexpected dangers in seemingly ordinary settings.
“The health risks of animal waste should not be underestimated.”

This incident serves as a grave reminder of the potential hazards in commercial agriculture, particularly those involving wildlife.

item.title: Worried About Osteoporosis? 4 Ways to Help Prevent the Disease - Yale Medicine
item.description:
Worried About Osteoporosis? 4 Ways to Help Prevent the Disease

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Yale Medicine

Osteoporosis is a serious condition that mainly affects older women by weakening their bones. This article discusses key steps to prevent osteoporosis or lessen its effects.

  • Osteoporosis affects an estimated 10 million Americans, with women making up 80% of those affected.
  • Proper nutrition, including calcium and vitamin D, is critical for bone health.
  • Weight-bearing exercises can strengthen bones and reduce the risk of fractures.
  • Fall prevention strategies are essential to avoid injuries related to osteoporosis.
“The big picture is that the benefits of these medications outweigh the risks, and their use merits a serious discussion between the patient and the provider.” - Dr. Clemens Bergwitz

Preventing osteoporosis involves a combination of lifestyle changes and, if necessary, medication. Regular check-ups and bone density tests can help monitor bone health over time.

item.title: Higher Ambient Levels of Air Pollutants Linked to Increased VTE Risk - Pulmonology Advisor
item.description:
Higher Ambient Levels of Air Pollutants Linked to Increased VTE Risk

Date: December 12, 2023 | Source: HealthDay News

The study indicates that chronic exposure to air pollution significantly elevates the risk of developing venous thromboembolism (VTE).

  • The research involved 6,651 participants from the Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis.
  • Participants were studied over a median follow-up of 16.7 years, during which 248 VTE events occurred.
  • Hazard ratios for VTE were reported as 1.39 for PM2.5, 2.74 for NO2, and 2.21 for NOx.
  • The study highlights that higher levels of specific air pollutants correlate with increased VTE risk.
“Chronic exposure to air pollution...adds to mounting evidence that air pollution adversely impacts health.”

This research emphasizes the health risks associated with air pollution and reinforces the need for public health measures to reduce pollution levels.

item.title: Doctors raise concern over rising lung cancers among non-smokers in India - DTNEXT
item.description:
Doctors raise concern over rising lung cancers among non-smokers in India

Date: Monday

Source: IANS

Lung cancer, traditionally affecting smokers, is increasingly seen in non-smokers in India, raising concerns among health experts, particularly due to rising air pollution.

  • Recent research indicates that most lung cancer patients in India are non-smokers.
  • Lung cancer is occurring approximately 10 years earlier in India than in Western countries.
  • There is a worrying trend of younger individuals, especially women, being diagnosed with lung cancer.
  • Key risk factors include air pollution, radon exposure, and indoor cooking fumes.
  • India reports around 75,000 new lung cancer cases annually, often diagnosed at advanced stages.
  • Advancements in treatment options include minimally invasive surgical techniques and targeted therapies.
“India's lung cancer demographic presents a unique and concerning picture...” - Dr. Prasad Adusumilli

This rising trend in lung cancer among non-smokers requires urgent attention to address environmental and lifestyle risk factors, alongside advancements in treatment to improve patient outcomes.

item.title: Flu virus remains infectious in refrigerated raw milk for up to 5 days - Tech Explorist
item.description:
Flu Virus Found to Remain Infectious in Refrigerated Raw Milk for Up to 5 Days

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Tech Explorist

This article discusses a new study from Stanford University indicating that the influenza virus can survive in refrigerated raw milk for up to five days, raising health concerns amid ongoing debates about the safety of raw milk.

  • Over 14 million Americans consume raw milk annually.
  • FDA has linked raw milk to over 200 illness outbreaks.
  • The study highlights risks of consuming raw milk, especially with recent outbreaks of bird flu in dairy cattle.
  • Infectious influenza virus remains in refrigerated raw milk for up to five days.
  • Cautions against potential transmission pathways for the virus.
  • The study emphasizes the importance of milk pasteurization in preventing diseases.
  • Prolonged presence of flu virus RNA detected in raw milk for at least 57 days.
“This work highlights the potential risk of avian influenza transmission through consumption of raw milk and the importance of milk pasteurization.” - Alexandria Boehm

The findings underscore the need for enhanced monitoring systems to track potentially harmful pathogens in dairy products, especially given the current concerns over bird flu's transmission.

item.title: Intermittent fasting may lead to hair loss, says Chinese study - South First
item.description: No summary available for this article. Click the link to read more.

item.title: 10 health, skin and fitness myths that must be busted before entering 2025 - The Indian Express
item.description:
10 Health, Skin, and Fitness Myths to Bust Before 2025

Publication Date: Not specified | Source: Indian Express

This article aims to educate readers about common misconceptions in health and fitness as they prepare for the new year. It highlights ten myths related to diet, hydration, skincare, and fitness, debunked by health experts.

  • Myth: Carbs are your enemy. Fact: Healthy carbs are essential for energy and brain function.
  • Myth: You need to drink eight glasses of water daily. Fact: Hydration needs vary per individual.
  • Myth: Expensive skincare equals better results. Fact: Skincare should match your skin type, not price.
  • Myth: Vaping is safer than smoking. Fact: Both harm lungs and lead to addiction.
  • Myth: Staying hungry leads to faster weight loss. Fact: It can slow metabolism and lead to binge eating.
  • Myth: Every glucose spike is a disaster. Fact: They are normal, but chronic spikes can indicate health issues.
  • Myth: Strength training will make women bulky. Fact: Women have lower testosterone levels, so they won't become bulky.
  • Myth: Drinking raw vegetable juices is the ultimate fix. Fact: Whole vegetables provide better nutrition.
  • Myth: A2 ghee is a miracle food. Fact: It is pure fat with no protein; moderation is key.
  • Myth: Seed oils are toxic. Fact: They can be part of a healthy diet if used in moderation.
“While ghee contains beneficial fats, it’s no cure-all.” - Dr. Birali Swetha

This article serves as a reminder to debunk popular myths and approach health decisions with more accurate information.

item.title: Honey and Lemon Hot Water 2024's Favourite Cold Remedy; Experts Share Why It Is The Timeless Elixir - Times Now
item.description:
Honey and Lemon Hot Water 2024's Favourite Cold Remedy; Experts Share Why It Is The Timeless Elixir

Publication Date: 2024

Source: Times Now

As the seasons change and the sniffles become more common, hot honey and lemon has gained renewed popularity in 2024 as a classic remedy for colds. Experts explain its effectiveness and benefits.

  • The drink combines honey and lemon, known for their antibacterial and immunity-boosting properties.
  • Many people reported relying on remedies like hot honey and lemon more than in previous years.
  • Preparation is simple, and it can be incorporated into daily routines for health benefits.
“A go-to drink for all ages during the winter season.” - Ruchi Sahay

This timeless elixir not only remedies colds but also supports overall well-being, making it an excellent addition to winter health routines.

item.title: What is 'Dinga Dinga', the excessive body-shaking disease leaving people in Uganda sick? - Firstpost
item.description:
What is 'Dinga Dinga', the excessive body-shaking disease leaving people in Uganda sick?

Publication Date: December 17, 2024
Source: Firstpost

A bizarre disease known as ‘Dinga Dinga’ has emerged in Uganda, causing uncontrollable body shaking primarily in women and children, and authorities are working to identify its cause.

  • First reported in Bundibugyo district, Dinga Dinga translates to “shaking like dancing” in the local dialect.
  • Symptoms include excessive body shaking, high fever, weakness, and challenges in walking.
  • Currently, approximately 300 cases have been documented with no reported fatalities.
  • The disease is treatable with antibiotics, although herbal remedies are discouraged.
  • Health authorities are on high alert and continue to monitor the situation closely.
“I felt weak and got paralyzed, with my body shaking uncontrollably whenever I tried to walk,” shared Patience Katusiime, a young patient.

As investigations continue, health officials stress the importance of seeking proper medical treatment to combat the outbreak.

item.title: GLP-1 RAs May Cut Risk for Late-Onset Epilepsy - Medscape
item.description:
GLP-1s May Reduce Risk of Late-Onset Epilepsy, Study Finds

Publication Date: December 9, 2024 | Source: Medscape Medical News

New research indicates that glucose-lowering drugs significantly reduce the risk of late-onset seizures and epilepsy, with GLP-1 receptor agonists showing the greatest effect.

  • GLP-1 receptor agonists (GLP-1 RAs) cut the risk of late-onset epilepsy by 33%.
  • The study included over 197,000 adults across 27 randomized controlled trials.
  • The findings were presented at the American Epilepsy Society Annual Meeting.
  • The research suggests that glucose management might impact neurological health in older adults.
  • Further studies are needed for definitive conclusions.
“This kind of research could contribute to ‘bringing down the epilepsy burden worldwide,’” said Udeept Sindhu, MD.

Considering the potential benefits, clinicians may want to consider GLP-1 RAs for older patients with cerebrovascular risks.

item.title: Bowel cancer cases are rising sharply in younger adult population - Clinical Trials Arena
item.description:
Bowel Cancer Cases Rising Sharply Among Younger Adults

Date: December 17, 2024 | Source: GlobalData Healthcare

Bowel cancer, which has a high incidence rate in developed countries, is increasingly being diagnosed in adults under 50, raising concerns about early detection and treatment strategies.

  • The incidence of bowel cancer in young adults is rising, whereas it has stabilized in older populations in multiple high-income countries.
  • A recent study published in Lancet Oncology found that early-onset colorectal cancer incidence rates increased in 27 out of 50 examined countries.
  • The largest increases in early-onset bowel cancer were noted in New Zealand (3.97%) and England (3.59%).
  • GlobalData forecasts a growth in diagnosed bowel cancer cases from 1.45 million in 2024 to 1.74 million by 2031.
  • Factors contributing to this increase include lifestyle, dietary habits, and alcohol consumption.
  • The UK NHS plans to lower the screening age to 50 by 2025 to enhance early detection efforts.
“The increase in incidence should still be a concern and close monitoring is required to identify the causes.”

This trend highlights the need for increased awareness and early screening approaches, particularly as lifestyle factors may be influencing rising incidence rates among younger populations.

item.title: PCOS and adrenal issues: Key signs you shouldn’t ignore - Hindustan Times
item.description:
PCOS and adrenal issues: Key signs you shouldn’t ignore

Publication Date: December 16, 2024
Source: Hindustan Times

This article discusses the signs of adrenal problems associated with Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) that individuals should not overlook, including symptoms like a puffy face and fatigue.

  • Symptoms of adrenal problems can include a puffy face due to high cortisol levels.
  • Fatigue may occur even with adequate sleep, suggesting hormonal imbalances.
  • Increased stress hormones can lead to belly fat and altered blood sugar levels.
  • Management strategies include walking and reducing caffeine intake.
“High cortisol levels lead to fluid accumulation, resulting in a swollen appearance.”

Recognizing these symptoms is crucial for managing health effectively and addressing potential adrenal issues early.

item.title: Lobia Dal: The nutrient-packed winter essential for energy and strength - CNBCTV18
item.description:
Lobia Dal: The Nutrient-Packed Winter Essential for Energy and Strength

Published December 17, 2024 by CNBC TV18

In winter, boost your health with Lobia dal, also known as cowpea or Chaula. It is a nutritious powerhouse of protein, vitamins, and fiber.

  • Winter Superfood: Lobia dal is packed with nutrients that strengthen the body and keep you energized all day long.
  • Nutrient-Rich & Energy-Boosting: A must-add to your diet for muscle power and vitality.
  • Immunity Boost in Every Bite: Recommended for increasing immunity with rich Vitamin C, A, and protein content.
  • Support for Diabetes Management: Helps regulate glucose levels, making it an excellent choice for diabetes patients.
  • A Healthy Boost for Animals: Feeding it to dairy animals can significantly increase milk production.
Disclaimer: Suggestions are for informational purposes. Please consult a qualified nutritionist or doctor before incorporating dietary changes.

Lobia dal offers numerous health benefits and can be a valuable addition to both human diets and animal feed.

item.title: US men lose their lives after using bat poop as fertiliser for cannabis plants - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Two US Men Die After Using Bat Guano as Cannabis Fertilizer

Date: Dec 17, 2024 Source: Hindustan Times

In a tragic case from Rochester, New York, two men lost their lives after inhaling fungal spores from bat droppings, known as guano, while attempting to use it as fertilizer for cannabis cultivation.

  • Both men developed serious respiratory infections caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, a fungus found in bat manure.
  • Despite medical interventions, they suffered respiratory failure and died.
  • The importance of public awareness regarding the risks associated with using bat guano for cultivation has been emphasized.
“It is crucial to raise awareness among both medical professionals and the public. Commercial fertilisers containing bat guano should be tested for Histoplasma capsulatum before reaching the market.”

This incident highlights the dangers of using bat guano without proper precautions and the growing incidents of histoplasmosis across the US.

item.title: Walk your way to happiness: Know the magic number of steps to lower depression risk - The Times of India
item.description:
Walking Your Way to Happiness: The Magic Number of Steps to Lower Depression Risk

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: Times of India

This article discusses the benefits of walking on mental health, specifically its effectiveness in reducing the risk of depression according to a new study from the University of Castilla–La Mancha.

  • The study analyzed data from over 96,000 adults and found that increased walking is associated with fewer depression symptoms.
  • Walking 5,000 steps improves mental health, while 7,000 or more steps significantly lowers depression risk.
  • Moderate and vigorous walking has been shown to enhance mental health, especially in older adults.
“More research is needed to clarify the potential protective role of daily steps in mitigating the risk of depression.”

In conclusion, integrating more walking into daily routines could contribute to better mental health and happiness.
